subject: Art
title: Wet-on-Wet Technique
description: Applying paint to a wet surface for soft, flowing, dreamlike effects.

hook.text: Wet the paper. Touch a loaded brush to the surface. Watch the color bloom outward in a soft, organic shape with no hard edges. This is wet-on-wet â€” watercolor's most atmospheric and unpredictable technique.

buildup.text: The wetness spectrum: soaking wet (paint flows far, very soft), damp (paint flows moderately), and barely wet (paint barely spreads, some edge control). Different wetness levels create different effects.

discovery.text: Timing is everything: too wet and the paint disappears into a watery puddle. Too dry and hard edges appear. The 'sweet spot' is a satin sheen on the paper â€” not puddling, not matte. Watch the surface shine to judge wetness.

twist.text: Wet-on-wet creates beautiful backgrounds, skies, and atmospheric effects â€” but it's nearly impossible to control precisely. The professional approach: use wet-on-wet for soft backgrounds, then add sharp details with wet-on-dry on top.

climax.text: Paint a simple sky: wet the top half of the paper, drop in blue and let it flow. While still damp, add a darker blue at the top for gradation. Let it dry, then paint sharp tree silhouettes on dry paper over it. Soft + sharp = drama.

punchline.text: Wet-on-wet is controlled chaos. Master the timing and you gain the most ethereal effects in all of painting.

quiz.question: What does the paper's surface look like at the ideal wetness for wet-on-wet?
options: A satin sheen â€” not puddling, not matte
